questions.neutral: Did you make it through the noise?

hobby.message: Found any new political literature lately?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: I made it. Quieter than usual tonight, I'd say.
Been at home, working with typewriters—restoring, actually.
No trouble unless the lights flicker again, that’s all.
Strange how even machines sense when things aren’t quite right.
Got through, yes. Noise outside feels different lately.
Spent the afternoon cleaning my old typewriter—Hermès 3000, if you know it.
Power blinked out mid-routine yesterday. First time in months.
Restoring these machines keeps the hands steady.
Things stumble when the system jitters, even for old hobbies.
I did, thanks. Seems the whole city is unsettled after the news, doesn’t it?
I usually pass the time with my typewriters—restoring them, writing letters on real paper.
Had a blackout just yesterday—lights dimmed, machines stalled.
Can’t even count on power for a proper ribbon change.
Feels like even private routines are being nudged off balance.
Strange times to be nostalgic for the mechanical.
I made it through. The streets almost hum with uncertainty since Halden’s passing.
I keep busy restoring typewriters—Hermès, Olympia, old relics you’d never see now.
Lost a full hour yesterday when the power cycled—couldn’t finish a single page.
It’s gotten harder to find fresh carbon ribbons or decent oil, too.
Last week, my pension transfer glitched; had to ration my paper.
After so many years around the Council, I still prefer the tangible click of keys.
Some days I think the machines notice the tension before I do.
I slipped through the noise, yes. Easier now I’m mostly forgotten, all told.
These days I live for my hobby: restoring antique typewriters, the old mechanical ones.
Used to keep Council notes on them in secret. Now, it’s just for myself.
Yesterday’s blackout killed half a letter to an old friend—haven’t had a power issue in years.
A few weeks back, I traced missing ink marks to a faulty mains relay—never needed to before.
Parts for repairs are nearly impossible, with the system’s slow collapse since Halden died.
Rumor is some blackout schedules are deliberate—reminders, or maybe just errors without him.
Strange comfort, holding something that works without permissions or an index score.
hobby_answer: Yes, I still tune them now and then.
Can’t seem to break old habits, even if the world changes.
When the grid stutters, it becomes less practical—timing is everything.
Not much else to say about it, really.
I keep to myself with it these days.
Yes, I still work on them.
Paper and ribbon are harder to come by lately.
Last blackout cut my session short. Systems failing everywhere, they say.
You notice how everything lags since Halden? Even hobbies feel delicate now.
I don’t like disruptions, but one gets used to them.
Mostly, I wait until things seem stable enough to continue.
I do. That old sound is a comfort.
Finding fresh ribbon’s gotten harder after the last system disruptions.
After Halden, the power’s unreliable—makes it tricky to keep a steady hand.
I lost a whole afternoon waiting for the lights to come back, just typing blindly.
Funny how a global event can shrink your private rituals.
Now I write shorter pieces, in case I get interrupted again.
Seems even hobbies must adapt.
Yes, still at it. Keeps me grounded, you know?
Restoring an old Hermès 3000 now, but parts are scarce—system breakdowns don’t help.
Had the power cut out on me mid-sentence after Halden passed; quiet was unsettling.
Old machines don’t like interruptions—neither do I.
Started stockpiling ribbons and paper, just in case.
Typewriters are resilient, but they reveal the cracks in the system.
Sometimes silence speaks louder than words on paper.
Makes you wonder what will falter next.
Absolutely—I still repair them, even now. Can’t let the tradition die.
Handwriting and typewriting feel safer than ever with recent instability.
Ever since Halden, every power dip or system error makes me cautious.
Once, I spent hours in the dark, half-finished page in the roller.
Shortages of parts and supplies... most suppliers rely on stable networks now.
I’ve hidden a few good ribbons; learned that trick long ago.
Neighbors don’t understand—it’s not nostalgia, it’s a safeguard.
In the Council days, we could trust routines. Now? Everything’s unpredictable.
That’s why I keep to paper—systems can’t erase what’s already printed.
